title: Oscars PwC accountant responsible for biggest gaffe in Academy Awards history 'posted tweet minutes before mix-up'
text:

The Pricewaterhouse Coopers accountant behind the worst mix-up in Oscars history reportedly tweeted minutes before the almighty blunder. 
Brian Cullinan is said to have uploaded a photo of Emma Stone backstage after she scooped the award for Best Actress for her role in La La Land. 
Minutes later he handed Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway the incorrect envelope. 
According to to the Wall Street Journal , Brian posted a picture of Emma at 9:05pm PST - three minutes before Best Picture was read out by the Bonnie and Clyde duo. 
"Best Actress Emma Stone backstage! #PWC,” it said alongside the picture. 
He also reportedly deleted a number of other tweets, while fellow PwC accountant Martha Ruiz - who was also in charge of handing out envelopes on the night - has left hers up. Warren Beatty speaks to Brian Cullinan (Photo: Rex Features) Brian Cullinan of Price Waterhouse and Coopers (PwC) holding the winners envelopes (Photo: Rex Features) 
The WSJ reports that the accounting firm - who has been responsible for calculating the results of the voting process and handing the envelopes to presenters for the past 83 years - has no comment on Bill’s tweets. 
Following the gaffe, PwC apologised unreservedly and said an investigation has begun into the cause of the blunder that has seen hundreds demand they have their contract with the awards terminated. 
The company said in a statement: "We sincerely apologise to Moonlight, La La Land, Warren Beatty, Faye Dunaway, and Oscar viewers for the error that was made during the award announcement for Best Picture. Warren Beatty holds the card for the Best Picture Oscar awarded to "Moonlight," (Photo: REUTERS) Warren Beatty and Brian Cullinan (Photo: Rex Features) 'La La Land' producer Fred Berger (R) speaks (Photo: Getty Images North America) 
"The presenters had mistakenly been given the wrong category envelope and when discovered, was immediately corrected. We are currently investigating how this could have happened, and deeply regret that this occurred. We appreciate the grace with which the nominees, the Academy, ABC, and Jimmy Kimmel handled the situation.” 
While in a statement to Variety, Tim Ryan, the accounting firm’s US chairman and senior partner, said: "Bill feels very, very terrible and horrible. 
“He is very upset about this mistake. And as a firm, given that he is a partner of our firm, it is also my mistake and our mistake and we all feel very bad.” 
On Sunday, chaos ensued at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood after Faye, 76, said that musical movie La La Land had won the evening's biggest award after she and Hollywood legend Warren, 79, were given the wrong envelope before stepping onto the stage. 
After being told there was a mix-up, La La Land producer Jordan Horowitz took to the mic and called up everyone who worked on Moonlight to the stage telling them that they were the real victors.
